stem: The nurse is caring for a 38-year-old male patient with a T6 spinal cord injury experiencing autonomic dysreflexia. Based on the assessment data, which interventions are the *MOST* appropriate for the nurse to implement *FIRST*? Select all that apply.

itemContext.sbar: S: Mr. Smith, 38-year-old male with T6 spinal cord injury, reporting severe headache and feeling flushed. BP elevated. B: Admitted 3 days ago for scheduled skin graft to sacral pressure ulcer. History of autonomic dysreflexia. A: At 0700 BP 110/70 mmHg. At 0930 BP 210/110 mmHg, HR 55 bpm, diaphoretic above injury level. Complaining of pounding headache, alert and oriented x4. Last bowel movement yesterday. A: Suspect autonomic dysreflexia. Placed in sitting position. Need orders for immediate interventions to lower BP and identify/alleviate cause.

topicTags: Neurological: Spinal Cord Injury & Autonomic Dysreflexia

rationale.correct:
Elevating the head of the bed to a high-Fowler's position helps lower blood pressure by promoting venous pooling in the lower extremities. Assessing for bladder distension is crucial because a full bladder is a common trigger for autonomic dysreflexia. Checking for fecal impaction is essential as bowel distension is another common cause. Administering antihypertensive medication, such as hydralazine, is indicated to rapidly lower the dangerously high blood pressure. Loosening tight clothing can help alleviate external pressure and reduce stimulation contributing to the autonomic response. 

clinicalPearl: Rapid blood pressure reduction is critical to prevent stroke or other complications.
rationale.incorrect:
Administering acetaminophen is not a priority intervention for autonomic dysreflexia. While the patient reports a headache, it is a symptom of the underlying autonomic dysreflexia; addressing the cause will alleviate the headache. Acetaminophen will not address the dangerously high blood pressure. Monitoring oxygen saturation is important in all patients, but in this case, the patient's oxygen saturation is already at 99% on room air, so it is not a priority intervention. Increasing the oxygen flow rate is not indicated and may not address the underlying cause. Applying restraints is contraindicated. The patient is not a threat to himself or others. Autonomic dysreflexia is a physiological response, not a behavioral one. Restraints would only agitate the patient and potentially worsen the situation.

clinicalPearl: Untreated autonomic dysreflexia can lead to severe hypertension, stroke, myocardial infarction, and death.
clinicalPearls: Autonomic dysreflexia is a medical emergency requiring immediate intervention.
The most common triggers are bladder and bowel distension, but any noxious stimulus below the level of injury can trigger the response.
Always prioritize identifying and removing the cause of the dysreflexia.

questionTrap.trap: Selecting interventions based only on the headache complaint and not recognizing the underlying autonomic dysreflexia.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Carefully analyze all assessment data to identify patterns and prioritize interventions based on the most critical physiological needs. In this case, the severely elevated blood pressure is the priority.

mnemonic.title: SIT UP
mnemonic.expansion: S: Sit the patient up (high-Fowler's). I: Investigate the cause (bladder, bowel, skin). T: Treat the blood pressure. U: Unfasten tight clothing. P: Prevent future occurrences.

options.text: Elevate the head of the bed to a high-Fowler's position.
options.rationale: Elevating the head of the bed helps to lower blood pressure by promoting venous pooling in the lower extremities, reducing venous return to the heart, and subsequently decreasing cardiac output and blood pressure. This is a crucial first step in managing autonomic dysreflexia. The goal is to reduce the patient's blood pressure as quickly as possible to prevent end-organ damage. Mnemonic: SIT UP - 'S' stands for Sit the patient up.

options.text: Administer acetaminophen 650 mg PO for headache.
options.rationale: While the patient reports a headache, it is a symptom of the underlying autonomic dysreflexia. Addressing the cause of the dysreflexia will alleviate the headache. Acetaminophen will not address the dangerously high blood pressure and is not a priority intervention. Question Trap: Selecting interventions based only on the headache complaint and not recognizing the underlying autonomic dysreflexia.

options.text: Assess for bladder distension and catheterize if necessary.
options.rationale: A full bladder is a common trigger for autonomic dysreflexia. Catheterizing the patient to relieve bladder distension can quickly lower blood pressure. This intervention addresses the underlying cause of the autonomic response. Clinical Pearl: The most common triggers are bladder and bowel distension, but any noxious stimulus below the level of injury can trigger the response.

options.text: Check the patient for fecal impaction.
options.rationale: Bowel distension from fecal impaction is another common cause of autonomic dysreflexia. Removing the impaction can help to resolve the autonomic response. This intervention addresses the underlying cause of the autonomic response. Clinical Pearl: Always prioritize identifying and removing the cause of the dysreflexia.

Hydralazine is an antihypertensive medication that can rapidly lower blood pressure. Given the severity of the patient's hypertension (210/110 mmHg), administering hydralazine is indicated to prevent end-organ damage. Mnemonic: SIT UP - 'T' stands for Treat the blood pressure.

options.text: Monitor oxygen saturation and increase oxygen flow rate to 6 L/min via nasal cannula.
options.rationale: The patient's oxygen saturation is already at 99% on room air, so increasing the oxygen flow rate is not indicated and may not address the underlying cause of the autonomic dysreflexia. This is not a priority intervention. The priority is to lower the blood pressure and identify the cause of the autonomic dysreflexia.

options.text: Apply restraints to prevent the patient from harming himself.
options.rationale: Restraints are contraindicated. The patient is not a threat to himself or others. Autonomic dysreflexia is a physiological response, not a behavioral one. Restraints would only agitate the patient and potentially worsen the situation. Restraints can also cause skin breakdown and further increase the risk of infection.

options.text: Loosen any tight clothing or constrictive devices.
options.rationale: Loosening tight clothing can help alleviate external pressure and reduce stimulation that may be contributing to the autonomic response. This is a simple intervention that can provide immediate relief. Mnemonic: SIT UP - 'U' stands for Unfasten tight clothing.
